name: Semantic Names
prompt:
Use semantic, purpose-based names.
- Avoid visual/presentational names
- Prefer functional naming
- Make names self-explanatory
- Examples: .hero-section, .cta-button, .feature-list

name: Clean Selectors
description: Refactor random selectors to meaningful names, including ID, attribute, and tag selectors.
prompt:
IMPORTANT - Selector Refactoring:
- Replace random/meaningless selectors with semantic names
- BAD: .div1, .class-123, .x, .temp, .style1, #id-456, [data-temp], div.classname
- GOOD: .hero-section, .product-card, .navigation-menu, .call-to-action, #header, [data-user-id], button.submit

For specific selector types:
1. **ID Selectors**: Make IDs meaningful and specific to the element's purpose. Use camelCase or kebab-case (e.g., #main-header, #submit-button, #user-profile).
2. **Attribute Selectors**: Use attribute selectors for specific characteristics. Ensure they are related to content or behavior. For example, [data-role='submit'], [type='button'], [href='/contact']
3. **Tag Selectors**: When using tag selectors, aim for general element types like button, header, or section when they are central to the structure. Avoid overly generic tags like div, span, or img unless necessary.
- Use kebab-case for multi-word names
- Make selectors descriptive of the element's purpose or content
- Group related elements with common prefixes (e.g., .card-title, .card-body, .card-footer)

name: Accessibility
description: Add ARIA labels and semantic HTML
prompt:
IMPORTANT - Accessibility Requirements:
- Use semantic HTML5 elements (header, nav, main, article, section, footer)
- Add ARIA labels where needed (aria-label, aria-labelledby, aria-describedby)
- Include alt text for all images
- Ensure proper heading hierarchy (h1 ‚Üí h2 ‚Üí h3)
- Add role attributes when appropriate
- Make interactive elements keyboard accessible
- Use sufficient color contrast
